Sateesh,

Lets suppose, for the sake of discussion, that the time required to
build test cases is equal to the time required to perform manual
testing.

Once.

Now think about the time required to do regression testing after a
change. Automated test cases can be re-run in a fraction of the time
required to repeat the manual testing.

In addition, after a functional change, the only test cases to build
are tests for the new functionality or maintenance against tests which
work against functionality that has been modified. Doing that
maintenance, and then running all tests, is faster and more reliable
than repeating all testing (new and old) manually. The effect is
cumulative.

Hope this helps!

-jn-

On Wed, Mar 26, 2008 at 2:36 AM, Sateesh
<sateeshkumar.soundarapandian@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Hi,
>  In our application, we planned to use JUnit. but our application is
>  like fetching, inserting, updating data in the databases. there is no
>  domain bussiness logics involved. that is there will be no
>  calculations etc., We feel that for our application testing could be
>  done manually. Even if we try with JUnit, the time taken for test case
>  preparation is almost equal to the time taken to implement the
>  functionality. Pls instruct me.
>
>  with regards,
>  Sateesh
